#Text=Cut Vinyl Records
#Text=If you have an old vinyl record that 's unplayable or scratched , upcycle it instead of throwing it away .
#Text=You can make art , designs , jewelry , and much more by cutting the record .
#Text=By heating the record or by using a hotknife , you can easily cut your vinyl into whatever shape you need !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Heating the Record in the Oven
#Text=Preheat the oven to .
#Text=Put one of the racks in the center position .
#Text=Turn on the oven and let it heat completely .
#Text=If you want to make a specific design , draw it on the record with a pencil before you heat it .
#Text=Put the vinyl record in the oven for 2-3 minutes .
#Text=Set the record on the center rack .
#Text=It can go directly into the oven or onto a baking tray .
#Text=Turn on the oven ’s interior light if it has one so you can watch the vinyl heat .
#Text=Use oven mitts to take the vinyl out of the oven before it starts to droop or melt .
#Text=The heat softens the vinyl , making it easier to cut .
#Text=Leave your oven on until you ’re completely finished with your cuts in case you need to reheat your vinyl .
#Text=Cover a baking tray with aluminum foil before putting the vinyl record on it .
#Text=This protects the baking tray from any melted vinyl .
#Text=Use a utility knife or pair of heavy-duty scissors to cut the record .
#Text=Set the vinyl on a flat heat-safe cutting surface .
#Text=Hold the record still with an oven mitt or potholder so it does n’t move around when you cut it .
#Text=Follow along with your design with a sharp knife or pair of scissors .
#Text=Make sure you use a sharp blade to make your cuts .
#Text=Put the record back in the oven if it hardens .
#Text=As you work with the vinyl , it will start to solidify as it loses temperature .
#Text=Set the record back on the center rack of your oven for 1-2 minutes to soften it to a workable temperature again .
#Text=Repeat this as many times as you need until you ’ve finished cutting your vinyl record .
#Text=Turn off your oven when you make your last cuts .
#Text=Smooth the edges of the vinyl with fine-grit sandpaper .
#Text=Use a 120 to 300-grit sandpaper to finish the edges where you made your cuts .
#Text=This ensures they are n’t jagged or sharp so you can easily handle the record afterward .
#Text=Using a Hotknife
#Text=Buy a hot knife from an arts and crafts store .
#Text=Hot knives are heated cutting tools used in crafts and woodworking to precisely cut delicate materials like vinyl or foam .
#Text=Visit your local crafts store and look for a hot knife with a sharp blade attachment .
#Text=Check a home improvement store if an arts and crafts store does n’t carry hot knives .
#Text=Plug the hot knife in and let it heat up .
#Text=Turn on the knife and set it so the blade is off of your work surface .
#Text=Wait 2-3 minutes for the blade to heat up or else your knife wo n’t make smooth cuts .
#Text=Do not touch the blade of the knife once it ’s heated .
#Text=Work on a wooden or heat-resistant surface so your knife does n’t burn through it when you make your cuts .
#Text=Keep the knife out of children ’s reach .
#Text=Many hot knives will have a built-in stand to hold the blade off the table .
#Text=Poke the knife through the record and pull it along your design .
#Text=Slowly stab the tip of the hot knife through the vinyl record .
#Text=Once you ’re through the vinyl , pull the knife at a steady speed along the line you want to cut .
#Text=Follow all of your lines until you ’ve completely cut out your design .
#Text=Turn off the knife and let it cool down once you finish .
#Text=Vinyl contains chlorine gas that could escape when it ’s heated .
#Text=Wear a facemask while cutting the vinyl with a hotknife .
#Text=Do n’t hold the knife in one spot for too long or else the vinyl will melt and bubble .
#Text=Keep the knife stationary and move the record with your other hand if that ’s more comfortable .
#Text=Punch the vinyl pieces when you finish cutting them .
#Text=Hold the cutout portion of vinyl against the table with your non-dominant hand .
#Text=Start gently pulling the rest of the record off your work surface with your dominant hand to separate the pieces .
#Text=For more intricate pieces , hold the cutouts as close to the edge as possible so they do n’t break off when you try to separate the pieces .
#Text=Making Crafts
#Text=Transform the record label into a coaster .
#Text=Heat the record in the oven at for 3 minutes .
#Text=Once the oven is heated , use a pair of scissors to cut out the label in the center .
#Text=Once you have the record down to size , trace it onto a piece of felt and cut it out .
#Text=Attach the felt to the bottom of the record label with spray adhesive .
#Text=Make sure to cover the hole in the center of the record , or else the liquid could still damage your table .
#Text=Cut the record into decorative wall art .
#Text=Draw a design on the record using a number 2 pencil before you start cutting it .
#Text=Cut your design out of the vinyl using either a hotknife or utility knife .
#Text=Hang the record on your wall either using adhesive strips or with a nail through the center hole .
#Text=To get inspiration for your art , look at the name of the record and think of a theme that relates to the song or album title .
#Text=Make wrist cuffs out of vinyl strips .
#Text=Cut out strips out of the record and put them on a baking tray .
#Text=Place the tray in an oven heated to for about 3-4 minutes .
#Text=Once you remove the baking sheet , shape the vinyl strip to fit around your wrist by wrapping it around a rolling pin .
#Text=If you need to reshape or resize the vinyl , put it back in the oven for 1 minute to soften it again .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Vinyl releases chlorine gas when heated .
#Text=Wear a facemask so you do n’t inhale any of the fumes .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Heating the Record in the Oven
#Text=Oven
#Text=Utility knife
#Text=Heavy-duty scissors
#Text=Sandpaper
#Text=Baking sheet ( optional )
#Text=Using a Hotknife
#Text=Hotknife
#Text=Wooden work surface
#Text=Facemask
#Text=Making Crafts
#Text=Oven
#Text=Scissors
#Text=Felt
#Text=Pencil
#Text=Hotknife
#Text=Rolling pin
#Text=Baking sheet
